div.h1: Shelf life: Identifying the abandonment of online digital humanities projects

div.div:
Electronic Textual Cultures Laboratory, University of Victoria,
Canada

Correspondence: Luis Meneses, Electronic Textual Cultures Laboratory, University of Victoria, Mearns Centre / McPherson Library A314, 3800 Finnerty Road (Ring Road), Victoria, BC, V8P 5C2, Canada. E-mail:ldmm@uvic.ca

Center for the Study of Digital Libraries, Texas A&M University,
USA
Search for other works by this author on:
Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 34, Issue Supplement_1, December 2019, Pages i129–i134, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqy079

div.p: Luis Meneses, Richard Furuta, Shelf life: Identifying the abandonment of online digital humanities projects, Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 34, Issue Supplement_1, December 2019, Pages i129–i134, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqy079

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

section.p: A large portion of the research carried out in the digital humanities has an online digital object (usually referred as a project) as one of its components. In turn, these online digital objects can be catalogued as distributed resources, which implies that the administrative control of information related to a topic may be spread across online resources and/or collections maintained by multiple scholars in different institutions. This administrative decentralization can lead to changes in content that are often unexpected by a researcher, which can be caused by different factors or circumstances. This reasoning led us to formulate the following question: When can online digital humanities projects be considered abandoned? In this article, we carry out a study on the persistence and average life span of online projects in the digital humanities. More specifically, we will elaborate on their reliance on distributed resources and methods for measuring their shelf life: the average length of time that a digital project can endure without updates until it can ultimately be considered abandoned by its researcher.

div.p: The Internet, along with the advent of online technologies, has provided researchers with greater opportunities to collaborate. Taking our research as an example, we have collaborated in creating online art catalogs (Meneses et al. 2011), interfaces for visualizing and creating poetry (Meneses et al. 2013), and tools for analyzing and exploring Shakespeare’s plays (Meneses et al. 2015, 2016a). However, the convenience and familiarity of computer networks makes us forget (or overlook) that there is a certain fragility associated with our online tools. In turn, this fragility threatens the completeness and the sustainability of our work over time (Kraus, 2011).

Nowadays, a large portion of the research carried out in the digital humanities has an online digital object (usually referred as a project) as one of its components. In turn, these online digital objects can be catalogued as distributed resources, which implies that the administrative control of information related to a project may be spread across online resources and/or collections maintained by multiple scholars in different institutions. This administrative decentralization can lead to changes in content that are often unexpected by a researcher, which can be caused by different factors or circumstances.

Changes can occur because of deliberate actions on part of the researcher—for example, reorganization of the structure of the collection, switching to a different content management system, or changing jobs and institutions. Changes might also be due to unexpected events—earthquakes, power outages, and disk failures—or may be due to other uncontrollable factors—death, seizure of computers by law enforcement, or termination of the services from an Internet Service Provider (McCown and Nelson, 2009). These changes can cause online resources to show signs of degradation when they break down and deteriorate.

Over time, great strides have been made to harness and manage the fragility of online resources. Studies have been carried out to address their potential reconstruction (Klein et al. 2011), the overall decay of websites (Bar-Yossef et al. 2004), and the decomposition of their shared resources (SalahEldeen and Nelson, 2012). Nevertheless, and despite these previous efforts, managing and characterizing change in online environments is a complex problem.

Recently, our research has been focusing on analyzing the perceptions of change in distributed collections and how detection methods based on machine learning algorithms perform against the assessment made by human subjects in a user study (Meneses et al. 2016b). However, we believe that the inherent characteristics of online digital humanities projects present an interesting (and unique) area for inquiry for two reasons. First, the research aspect of digital humanities projects hinders previous approaches—as the methods for identifying change in the Web do not fully apply. And second, digital humanities projects have a limited useful life. This useful life is accompanied by research from a primary investigator—which may or may not be indicated by updates in the project’s content and tools. We have seen many cases of successful projects in digital humanities (that fulfill their original objectives and achieve their expected level functionality) that are shifting their focus from active development to data management. Examples of this transition include the Cervantes Project (http://cervantes.tamu.edu) and the TAMU Herbaria Project (http://botany.csdl.tamu.edu/). This change in focus might be caused by a different set of reasons—which are not often apparent to its users—such as loss of funding, change in personnel or simply decay in interest. We believe that all these reasons are worthy of study.

All this reasoning led us to formulate the following question: When can online digital humanities projects be considered abandoned? In this article, we carry out a study on the persistence and average life span of online projects in the digital humanities. More specifically, we will elaborate on their reliance on distributed resources and methods for measuring their shelf life: the average length of time that a digital project can endure without updates until it can ultimately be considered abandoned by its researcher.

A complete listing of research projects in the Digital Humanities does not exist. However, the Alliance of Digital Humanities Organizations publishes a Book of Abstracts after each Digital Humanities conference. Each one of these volumes can be treated as a compendium of the research that is carried out in the field. To create a data set, we downloaded the Books of Abstracts corresponding from 2006 to 2016—except for 2015 which was not available for download. The Books of Abstracts were all in the PDF format.

Then we proceeded to extract the text from these documents using Apache Tika and parse 5,845 unique URLs using regular expressions. Then we used Python’s Requests Library to retrieve the HTTP response codes and headers corresponding to the URLs, which we used to classify the websites by their year of publication (the first time they were mentioned in the Books of Abstracts) into two groups depending on the status of its server response. We use this classification as a measure of their correctness: valid (correct and successful request) and decayed (showing signs of degradation and requiring additional actions to complete the request). This process was limited to the home page of each site. Fig. 1 shows the distribution of decay for each year, while Fig. 2 shows a breakdown of the HTTP response codes by year grouped by their class of response. Table 1 lists the classes for HTTP response status codes.
Classes for HTTP response status codes

tr.td: 2×× (Success)
The request was successfully received, understood, and accepted
3×× (Redirection)
Further action needs to be taken to complete the request
4×× (Client Error)
The request contains bad syntax or cannot be fulfilled
5×× (Server Error)
The server failed to fulfill an apparently valid request

The request was successfully received, understood, and accepted
3×× (Redirection)
Further action needs to be taken to complete the request
4×× (Client Error)
The request contains bad syntax or cannot be fulfilled
5×× (Server Error)
The server failed to fulfill an apparently valid request

div.p: URL decay by year
URL decay by year
HTTP response codes by year
HTTP response codes by year

We must also address that the cataloging of the websites that returned HTTP redirects in the decayed category can grant further discussion—mostly because URL shortners will initially return a response code in the 300 range. However, we have found that HTTP redirects can be considered as early indicators of degradation which is why we decided to place them into this category. There are sophisticated and problematic cases in which a Web server reports change in a human-readable, but not machine-readable format. These sophisticated and problematic cases can occur intentionally (for example, attempting to provide a ‘friendly’ or ‘soft’ way to allow the reader to continue by redirecting failed pages to the site’s index page), without knowledge of the original site (for example, the landing page provided by an academic institution when an address that refers to a host that is no longer available), or deceptively (for example, the registration of lapsed domain names and uploading a different Web site as an attempt to sell the domain name back to its original holder). Given that the nature of this experiment is primarily exploratory, these cases do not significantly affect the conclusions and outcome of our findings.

This study is an attempt to categorize change in a very specific domain. As an attempt of categorization, determining the degree of abandonment affecting a digital project over time is a difficult task. A Web resource may gradually degrade from being correct to one that is still of some use by providing access to related information or details about its parent institution. Abandonment can also be hinted by changes in Web servers, directory structures, etc., which may cause Web requests to still result in successful responses from a server, yet provide no valid information to the requestor. Based on our preliminary findings, we approximate the average shelf life of a digital humanities project to 5 years—which aligns with reports from previous work (Goh and Ng, 2007). The average time in years since the last modification of the websites in the study is shown in Fig. 3.

img.alt: Average time in years since last modification

div.p: Average time in years since last modification

img.alt: Average time in years since last modification

div.p: Average time in years since last modification

Additionally, we believe that ‘abandonment’ is not necessarily a sufficient designation—as there are different nuances involved. We will proceed to elaborate on these nuances using one of our online projects as an example. Digital Acting Parts (http:digitalactingparts.tamu.edu) is an online project that encourages active reading and memorization, which in turn leads to a better understanding of Shakespeare’s plays. The project has been active since 2013, but online development has shifted to a set of different processes that are carried out behind the scenes. Consequently, the project’s online presence has not been updated for some time now (we estimate that it has been at least a year). However, the online tools are quite stable at this point. In this specific case, the lack of updates and new content is not a signal of abandonment. This is clear example of why the rules for traditional websites do not fully apply and new metrics are needed to identify issues concerning online projects in the digital humanities.

Our study also intends to raise awareness over a challenging problem: how to counter the effects of degradation. Furthermore, this study lays the groundwork toward formulating potential strategies for the archival and the long-term preservation of abandoned digital online projects. It is important to highlight that different levels of preservation and curation are needed among digital projects. Historically, preservation efforts have been primarily concerned with maintaining the primary artifacts in collections, relegating descriptive metadata to a lesser level of importance. There is an underlying notion that descriptive metadata is static: requiring minimal resources to maintain and consequently making it easier to preserve. However, our previous work (Meneses et al. 2016b) has shown that this is not always the case. The analysis that we have described in this article is invested in the more basic question of identifying the factors that enable the effects.

For future installments of our work, we plan to include additional metrics such as number of redirects, Domain Name System (DNS) metadata, and a more detailed analysis of content features. This will allow us to create a taxonomy that illustrates the life cycle of digital projects. More so, we believe that most of the degradation problems stem from the distributed architecture of the Web itself. An embedded versioning system and unique identifiers for documents—as proposed by Nelson’s Xanalogical structures (Nelson, 1999)—could potentially solve some of the more pressing problems. However, these structures do not exist as an integral part of the Web, making it impossible to measure their impact and foresee if this change in infrastructure could bring forth a different set of problems.

To summarize, in this article we have focused on identifying indicators of the abandonment of digital humanities projects—as well as identifying their average life span. Digital online projects in the humanities have unique characteristics that make them impervious to the metrics that are used in the Web as a whole. In our opinion, these unique characteristics make them worthy of study. In the end, the purpose of this study is to gain a better understanding of digital humanities projects and their lifespan, and formulate better strategies for their long-term preservation.
